text:
So excited to be taking Instacart public today! The last two years have been a wild ride, but I‚Äôm really proud of the business this team has built, turning us into an enduring and profitable company that delivers a critical service to millions of people. 

None of this would have been possible without the early days determination and grit of our founders - Apoorva Mehta, Max Mullen and Brandon Leonardo. Thank you for the creative spark that founded Instacart and for entrusting me to lead the company‚Äôs next chapter.

One of the company values that I‚Äôm most proud of is ‚ÄúGrow the Pie‚Äù ‚Äî we are in the business of growing our partners' businesses and when they win, we win. It makes today‚Äôs milestone even more sweet as it's a win not just for us but for our retail partners, brand partners, customers, and shoppers. 

Yet, at the same time, it‚Äôs just the beginning. My eyes are firmly set on the next 10 years of building technologies to transform the largest retail category in the world. So, while we savor today‚Äôs milestone, we‚Äôre going to stay hungry and work to create value in the public markets the same way we always have ‚Äî by lifting others up and growing the pie for everyone.

Asha Sharma Nick Giovanni Dani Dudeck Laura Jones Varouj Chitilian Daniel Danker JJ Zhuang Christina Hall (she/her) Morgan Fong Chris Rogers Max Mullen Apoorva Mehta Brandon Leonardo

Big news today. Below is what I sent to my Instacart team just now, and the link points to Sam‚Äôs statement. 

Hi team - I want to share an important update with you that I will be leaving Instacart in the coming months to take on a new role as CEO of OpenAI Applications, leading the product, business, and other company functions. 

Let me start by saying this was an incredibly hard decision because I love this company. We are operating incredibly well as our last earnings results have shown. Our strategy is working and this team is top notch, which makes it very hard to leave. 

At the same time, you all know my passion for AI generally and in particular for the potential it has to cure diseases ‚Äî the ability to lead such an important part of our collective future was a hard opportunity to pass up. I only feel comfortable doing this because Instacart is on an excellent track and in great hands with a stellar management team. 

I want to be clear that this change is not immediate. I‚Äôm not going anywhere for a couple of months. Our board regularly conducts succession planning exercises, and we expect the new CEO will be announced soon and will be an existing member of our management team. I‚Äôll remain CEO and work closely with my successor and our leadership team to ensure a smooth handoff. I‚Äôll also stay on as Chair of the Board to support our next CEO. 

I also want to apologize for how unexpected this may feel. This is not how I planned for you all to hear this news, but a media leak unfortunately expedited the timeline by several weeks.

Leading Instacart and being on this journey with you has been an honor. From resetting growth in the post-pandemic years and proving to the world that we could be profitable, to successfully taking this company public and hitting $1B in an annual advertising & other revenue run rate, to expanding to restaurants and transforming the in-store experience with Caper Carts, and even just this week launching a completely new app, Fizz, in record time  ‚Äî we have proven that we can take any challenges and turn them into massive opportunities. I‚Äôm deeply proud of the work we‚Äôve done together and even more excited about the road ahead. 

Fidji.

https://lnkd.in/eBJuDaW6

I will officially start at OpenAI as CEO of Applications on August 18. I am sharing this essay on why I believe AI can be the greatest source of empowerment for all. https://lnkd.in/gfrq627N 

I‚Äôve always considered myself a pragmatic technologist ‚Äî someone who loves technology not for its own sake, but for the direct impact it can have on people‚Äôs lives. That‚Äôs what makes this job so exciting, since I believe AI will unlock more opportunities for more people than any other technology in history. If we get this right, AI can give everyone more power than ever.

But I also realize those opportunities won‚Äôt magically appear on their own.

Every major technology shift can expand access to power ‚Äì the power to make better decisions, shape the world around us, and control our own destiny in new ways. But it can also further concentrate wealth and power in the hands of a few ‚Äî usually people who already have money, credentials, and connections.

That‚Äôs why we have to be intentional about how we build and share these technologies so they lead to greater opportunity and prosperity for more people. The choices we make today will shape whether the coming transformation leads to greater empowerment for all, or greater concentration of wealth and power for the few.

We can start by making sure the keys to empowerment and opportunity ‚Äî knowledge, health, creative expression, economic freedom, time, and support ‚Äî are widely available. You can read more in the link I shared about the potential AI has to transform each of these aspects of people‚Äôs lives.

If we can make intelligence accessible everywhere, affordable to everyone, and easy to understand, we can drive the biggest opportunity engine the world has ever seen and help more people live better lives. I‚Äôm looking forward to building this future alongside my brilliant new colleagues at OpenAI, and I‚Äôll have a lot more to share soon.

Last day today! Being CEO of Instacart has been one of the greatest honors of my life, and I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs time to say goodbye. This job inspired and challenged me in all the best ways. Most of all, it connected me with an incredible group of people who poured their hearts into the work because helping people put food on the table is one of the most noble things you can do. 
I'm so proud of what we built together over the last 4 years, and I leave knowing that the company couldn't be in better hands than with Chris Rogers who has the vision and drive to accelerate us into the next chapter. Thank you to the entire team - my heart and my fridge will always be full thanks to my time at Instacart. ü•ïüíö

ChatGPT Atlas is here! Our new browser has ChatGPT built in so it can help you across the web and, if you want, remember what you‚Äôve done online and use that context for future requests. More of my thoughts on why we built this here: https://lnkd.in/e-4quua7

One of the things I‚Äôm most excited about with ChatGPT is how it‚Äôs revolutionizing healthcare. GPT-5 is our best model yet for answering health questions. It scores significantly higher than any previous model on HealthBench, an evaluation OpenAI published earlier this year based on realistic scenarios in partnership with over 250 physicians. 
Felipe, a member of our OpenAI team, and his wife Carolina shared their story on today‚Äôs livestream, and it really moved me. Last October, Carolina was hit with three cancer diagnoses in one week. Like many, her biopsy results felt overwhelming and confusing. On a whim, she took a screenshot of the biopsy report and put it into ChatGPT. Within seconds, it translated the medical jargon into plain language, helping her feel more in control and more prepared to talk to her doctor about next steps. She‚Äôs kept using ChatGPT throughout her cancer journey, even to help make a tough choice about radiation when doctors gave conflicting advice. It‚Äôs incredible to hear how ChatGPT restored her sense of agency during these critical decisions. You can watch the full livestream and their story here:

Today we‚Äôre beginning to roll out parental controls in ChatGPT, including the first-of-its-kind safety notification system to alert parents if their teen may be at risk of self-harm. Read more here:¬†https://lnkd.in/g9e5sAug

Whenever I talk with people about AI, one of the first questions I get is almost always: what will this mean for my job? I believe AI will open up more opportunities than any technology in history ‚Äì but it will also change how work gets done. Today we‚Äôre announcing OpenAI-Certified and the OpenAI Jobs Platform ‚Äì two new initiatives that are about helping people become fluent in AI and connecting them with employers who need their skills. We can‚Äôt eliminate the disruption AI will bring, but we can make sure the benefits are shared broadly, not just by a fortunate few. This is one big step in the right direction.

What a dream come true. Growing up in France and now living my American dream, it was such an honor to be invited to the state dinner hosted by President Macron honoring President Biden at the √âlys√©e Palace. Such a special evening to celebrate the partnership of these two countries that mean so much to me. Merci Monsieur le Pr√©sident and Madame Macron for the most memorable night!
Big change to our product today: instead of waiting for you to ask questions, ChatGPT anticipates your needs and starts working work on your behalf. Read more here:

GPT-5.2 is here and it‚Äôs the best model out there for everyday professional work.

On GDPval, the thinking model beats or ties human experts on 70.9% of common professional tasks like spreadsheets, presentations, and document creation. It‚Äôs also better at general intelligence, writing code, tool calling, vision, and long-context understanding so it can unlock even more economic value for people.

Early feedback has been excellent and I can‚Äôt wait for you to try it:
Grateful to be on the TIME 100 AI list; in my interview, I talk about how I want to guide the deployment of AI to be maximally useful to people while mitigating its inherent risks.

Last month I gave an update on the journey I‚Äôve been on to find cures for complex chronic conditions like the ones I suffer from. Today, I‚Äôm thrilled to announce that we‚Äôre launching ChronicleBio ‚Äî a company entirely dedicated to building the world‚Äôs best data platform on neuroimmune conditions like POTS, ME-CFS and Long COVID, that affect 250+ millions of people.

I‚Äôm honored to be co-founding ChronicleBio with Rohit Gupta and Rishi Reddy, who are the ones running the business full-time. The three of us are patients and caregivers in this space, so we have deep personal commitment to the mission.

For most conditions, like cancer or Parkinson's, critical datasets already exist and have massively accelerated the path to drugs. But for neuroimmune conditions, these datasets are sorely missing, making it hard for biotech and pharma to invest in developing drugs.

The advances we‚Äôre seeing in AI make me more confident than ever that we‚Äôre on the cusp of being able to cure these diseases. But powerful models alone aren‚Äôt enough ‚Äî we also need rich, high quality, deeply-analyzed biological data that these AI models can be trained or deployed on.

ChronicleBio is here to provide exactly that.
We are bringing together providers, pharma and patients to generate the world‚Äôs largest and deepest multi-modal data set for our patient population, with the goal of surfacing new biological patterns, building biomarkers, and ultimately accelerating the path to diagnostics and treatments.

Within months we have already begun launching clinical partnerships, building a scalable data ingestion engine and biobanking infrastructure, generating brand awareness with relevant patient advocacy groups, generating revenue with pharma via a decentralized clinical trial network and assembling a world class mission-oriented team of AI technologists, scientists and healthcare leaders.

This work is personal. Behind every sample we collect, there is a patient suffering, fainting in random places, stuck in bed for years, or living with relentless, invisible symptoms. These conditions are profoundly debilitating ‚Äî and yet there are still no validated biomarkers, no diagnostics, no cures. That is unacceptable.

This is a long road, but like I‚Äôve said before: I will not rest until these conditions are eradicated. In the meantime, the team at ChronicleBio will build the data infrastructure that will make tomorrow‚Äôs cures possible, faster.

The launch of ChatGPT Health is really personal for me. I know how hard it can be to navigate the healthcare system (even with great care). AI can help patients and doctors with some of the biggest issues. More here:¬†https://lnkd.in/gq63gtAp

I‚Äôm excited to share that Chris Rogers  will become Instacart‚Äôs next CEO on August 15!

Working closely with Chris over the last four years, I‚Äôve seen his exceptional work ethic and decision making firsthand. Because everything we do is in partnership with our retail and brand partners, there isn‚Äôt a single thing we‚Äôve done in the last few years that Chris hasn‚Äôt had his fingerprints on. From our retail enablement strategy and omnichannel expansion to the massive growth and evolution of our advertising platform, Chris has been a driving force behind all of these initiatives. I look forward to continuing to work with him as I stay on as board chair. 

I truly believe Instacart is still just getting started and I know Chris and our leadership team will carry our mission forward and take us to even greater heights. Congratulations Chris!

Over 1 million business customers are now using OpenAI, the fastest-growing business platform in history.

AI is a tool of abundance. The most successful businesses use AI to multiply, not just cut. They‚Äôre launching new products faster and tackling many more great ideas that would have fallen below the line in the past. Let's build:

But with hundreds of millions of people using ChatGPT, one default personality won‚Äôt work for everyone. The new presets and improved custom instructions should make it easier for people to really make ChatGPT their own.¬†I wrote more about how we‚Äôre moving beyond one-size-fits-all.

What a surreal moment to see Instacart studied in a Harvard Business School classroom today! Hearing lots of smart students debating decisions we made for the last four years was such a fascinating experience. One of the most rewarding parts was seeing the principles we‚Äôve built the company on reflected so clearly in the HBS case (which will publish soon!). ‚ÄúGrow the pie‚Äù isn‚Äôt just something we say; it‚Äôs a core mindset that shapes how we operate at every level. 

Thank you, Harvard Business School, Leonard Schlesinger and Hubert Joly for sharing our story. And thank you to the entire Instacart team ‚Äî your work is what made it a story worth telling!

It‚Äôs really meaningful to see the work of transforming Instacart be recognized, especially since I‚Äôm lucky to do this in the company of amazing women on my leadership team who inspire me every day like Asha Sharma, Dani Dudeck, Christina Hall (she/her) and Laura Jones . Also a big shoutout to Sheryl Sandberg who helped so many of us believe that this was possible.

AI is already making a huge difference in health and education. Seeing a leading medical center go all-in like this makes me so hopeful about what‚Äôs possible.

We‚Äôve barely just launched Community Carts on Instacart and we are already delivering thousands of bags of groceries and daily essentials to emergency centers in LA. One of the leaders of a YMCA we work with was watching the cars pull up and said ‚Äúomg, what are these magical cars showing up with food we need so much of!‚Äù - magic indeed. So much emotion looking at all these bags growing by the minute, with many orders in excess of $1000+. In the middle of this tragedy, we‚Äôre really witnessing the best of humanity. And we‚Äôre just getting started. Thank you to everyone who is jumping on to help LA; you can donate items here: https://lnkd.in/gMPZtUTT

My family enjoyed taking Instacart‚Äôs Caper Carts for a spin on our last grocery trip at Bristol Farms in Santa Monica. Excited to see our smart carts hitting more and more stores and delivering such a smooth experience. Got a rave review from my toughest critic, my daughter, who is now begging to go back to the store for more Lucky Charms.

Very excited to unveil our Instacart Developer Platform so that third party apps - from Weight Watchers to New York Times Cooking to GE Appliances - can turn their food discovery apps into food delivery apps, leveraging all the leading capabilities we‚Äôve built over the last decade. I can‚Äôt wait to see the kind of innovation that Instacart will power.

So so proud of Vijaye Raji for taking Statsig to new heights and realizing his dream of creating a highly successful company that‚Äôs helping tons of startups make better data-driven decisions. He‚Äôs one of my very favorite people and there is no greater joy than seeing amazing people do their magic. I still remember the many times when we talked about him becoming a founder (despite me trying to keep him at Facebook for as long as I could). It was so fun to speak at his conference this morning - truly a full-circle moment. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I wrote about why AI‚Äôs greatest promise lies in making opportunities more widely shared, and the role that France and Europe can play in shaping that future. As someone deeply proud to be French, it‚Äôs inspiring to see how our country‚Äôs values and creativity are shaping the future of AI.

On the heels of our public debut earlier this week, I‚Äôm thrilled to welcome a new (but very familiar!) face to Instacart‚Äôs Board of Directors - Ravi Gupta, Partner at Sequoia Capital. 

Sequoia has been a long-term investor and a critical partner that has supported Instacart at every turn. As Instacart‚Äôs former CFO and COO, Ravi also has a deep understanding of our business. 

On a personal note, Ravi was incredibly helpful when I joined Instacart as CEO years ago, and he quickly became a trusted advisor on the business.

Welcome, Ravi - we‚Äôre thrilled to have you back at our table!

Big week for Instacart in Cannes! Retail media was the topic all brands wanted to talk about; between ads on Instacart across our 1,500+ retailers, ads on retailers‚Äô sites that we power, ads on our Caper carts in-store, and our retail media data powering ads on Google, YouTube, NBCu and more, Instacart is at the center of this conversation. We‚Äôre also starting to see real convergence of retail media teams and budgets with digital media ones, and CMOs and Chief Commercial Officers aligning their strategies more aggressively. It reminds me of the similar journey we went through at Facebook, where social/digital started as a small budget on the side, then became the heart of most media departments. It was incredibly fun to talk about these trends at WPP Beach with Adam Gerhart, and I‚Äôm so proud of the team for showcasing our work so well.

I was honored to speak at VivaTech today. I joined the wonderful Anthony Morel for a conversation about what it means to build at the intersection of retail, AI, and everyday life. We covered the transformation of Instacart into a grocery technology company, the future of in-store shopping powered by products like Instacart‚Äôs Caper Carts, how AI can be an augmentation layer, and the responsibility we carry as AI capabilities advance globally.

Merci to the VivaTech team and also to Thomas Urbain for a well-timed look at my career journey in AFP today - and thanks to my amazing colleagues David Marcus and Julien Codorniou for their contributions; very lucky to have worked with brilliant, supportive people throughout my career.

I had the privilege of delivering the commencement speech for the HEC Paris Class of 2025. These students are entering the workforce at a time of great transformation; in my speech, I give them some guidance on how to embrace this moment as the greatest accelerant to human potential, reconnect with their own power to create, and usher in their own golden age of creation. I can‚Äôt wait to see what they put out into the world!

Paul Graham‚Äôs ‚Äúfounder mode‚Äù essay made the rounds in the Valley (and beyond) this weekend. There is such magic in many founder-driven companies, but I strongly believe that we need non-founders to also act with a founder-mode mindset. With the right incentives, founder-led tech companies could become breeding grounds for other founder-mode leaders and CEOs. I saw this first hand at Meta, where Zuck made bets on entrepreneurial people and rewarded those of us who brought new products and businesses from 0-to-1, more than he valued team size or other ‚Äúmanager mode‚Äù proxies for success. I wrote more about this The Information today:

The future of grocery isn‚Äôt going to be a choice between offline and online ‚Äî it's going to be omnichannel. Retailers and brands who create a seamless experience across online and the store will gain an edge, and Instacart's technologies are helping them gain that edge. Introducing ads to our in-store Caper Carts marks the next, exciting phase of our Connected Stores strategy. With ads on Caper Carts, we‚Äôre combining the best of in-store shopping ‚Äî getting inspired as you browse the aisles ‚Äî with the best of online advertising:¬†personalization, measurability, and targetability. I caught up with¬†Caroline Hyde¬†to share more on our strategy - thanks for the great conversation,¬†Caroline!

It has been beyond devastating to see the extreme damage caused by the Los Angeles wildfires. To help do our part and offer support, Instacart is waiving delivery fees on groceries and other essential goods for orders over $10 in Los Angeles County. We hope that this provides some small relief to those navigating such a difficult time.¬†Please share with whoever needs this.

When you focus on the obstacles, they look bigger and things get harder. When you focus on your destination, the obstacles look smaller and you can find solutions to each one. Thank you, Chief, for the opportunity to talk about the importance of this mindset throughout my life!

So happy to see our Ask Instacart feature live in the app for consumers, and even more excited to see all the ways it will help make meal planning easier, faster and more inspiring for families (mine included!). More on the new feature and our partnership with OpenAI from Instacart Chief Architect JJ Zhuang via TechCrunch below. There‚Äôs so much more to come with AI and the future of food, health and Instacart - proud of this first step.

As much as it is important to celebrate successes, leadership is also about reflecting on the failures, pivots, and things that require many tries to get right. Hard things often do. 

After being diagnosed with POTS, I embarked on a mission to find cures for neuroimmune conditions, which are debilitating, and chronically understudied. I asked so many pharma companies why they weren't prioritizing conditions that affect 10s of millions of people in the U.S. alone, and the answer was clear: there simply was not enough high-quality data on the biological mechanisms behind these conditions, preventing pharma from identifying good targets and drugs. 

We decided to change this. In 2023, we proudly opened the doors to Metrodora, a state-of-the-art institute in Salt Lake City, to provide multidisciplinary clinical care for these patients, and allow them to volunteer their data and participate in research.

For two years, we tried everything to make the clinic work. We poured tens of millions of dollars into it, tried to reinvent how care can be delivered, explored every possible business model. Yet we could not find a way to make it sustainable. We offered insurance for everyone to have access, but insurance covers only a very small % of the cost of giving these complex patients the care that they so rightfully deserve. While the clinic was supposed to help fund the much-needed research, all of our funds were spent trying to keep the clinic alive instead, with no hope for sustainability and without being able to live up to the level of care we so badly wanted to give patients. 

This month we made the difficult decision to stop clinical services and to focus entirely on research. Research is critical and cures are what patients ultimately need. Yet I am still very disappointed that we couldn't crack a clinical model to help patients in the meantime, despite our determination. I really hope to see structural changes to the healthcare system, so other people can pick up that fight and make it happen better than we could. 

As for what's next: we‚Äôre going back to the core priority of gathering high quality data to understand these conditions better, and we‚Äôve made tremendous progress there. With the right data, AI provides an incredible opportunity to uncover new biological mechanisms. We‚Äôre more determined than ever to build the most comprehensive data platform for neuroimmune conditions. We‚Äôll continue to use our clinic as a clinical trial site and partner with other clinics as well. We‚Äôll have more to announce on this soon. 

I'm really hopeful that the advances in AI will allow us to understand biology much faster and accelerate the timeline for cures. Too many patients are living with debilitating symptoms (see article below) because treatments are not coming fast enough. So no matter what the obstacles, failures, bumps in the roads are, I will never stop fighting until we've eradicated these and all diseases.
Thanks Chief for including me in your top 50 execs for The New Era of Leadership awards!

50 years ago, the first barcode was scanned at a grocery store in Ohio ‚Äî¬† a pack of Juicy Fruit. Today, another digital transformation is in progress, with AI poised to shape the next 50 years of retail.

We‚Äôre also continuing to waive delivery fees on groceries and other essential goods for orders over $10 in Los Angeles County.

One year ago, we launched Instacart Health, introducing a new technology infrastructure that today is powering high-impact food as medicine and nutrition intervention programs across the U.S. It‚Äôs been a big year for Instacart Health, and a critically important year in healthcare as even more players began to focus on connecting food and nutrition to health outcomes. We‚Äôre seeing providers, payers, nonprofits, and research institutes (this list goes on!) putting more resources than ever before behind scaling these programs ‚Äî and we‚Äôre proud to help them do it. 

The one-year anniversary of Instacart Health felt like the perfect time to share an update on all the progress we‚Äôve made and all the collaborative work we still have to do. More on this in my newsletter today:

One of my goals in joining OpenAI was to build tools that help people feel more confident in their financial lives, because AI can be a meaningful source of economic empowerment.
So when Sasan Goodarzi approached me with this idea, we were immediately excited to deliver personalized, trusted financial intelligence directly in ChatGPT for people and businesses.

Instacart‚Äôs Caper Carts are leading the way in bringing edge AI to retail. In my newsletter today, I lay out the importance of edge AI and what it means for the future as we apply the power of AI to more parts of our physical world.

When I got sick five years ago, I asked all the biotech companies I knew why there weren‚Äôt more drugs developed for neuroimmune conditions despite the fact that they destroy the lives of tens of millions of people. They all said the same thing: there isn‚Äôt enough well-characterized patient data to understand these conditions at the biological level, making it really risky for pharma to invest.

At Metrodora Foundation, we‚Äôre now closing this gap. Today we‚Äôre officially launching MetX, our landmark study and set of data collection tools to collect 360 patient data across clinical data, wearables, biological samples, etc. That way, we‚Äôll get a full view of patients from their genetics to their immune system to their reported symptoms. And with the rise of AI, having the right data sets to be able to leverage all the advances in AI has only become more urgent. We‚Äôre excited to make these data sets available to any researcher who wants to push the field forward, and are grateful to all the other disease foundations that are joining us in this fight. I'm so proud of this work and so hopeful for what it might enable. Let‚Äôs go find cures. 

PS: Building these data sets isn‚Äôt cheap. Other disease foundations have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to build these. We believe we can do it much more efficiently thanks to the direct access to patients we have through Metrodora Institute, but every $100-500 you donate means one more genetic test or immune profiling test we can run on a patient, getting us closer to a full mapping of this population. We‚Äôre grateful for any help.

This was a special podcast because I‚Äôve admired Mark Hyman, MD for a long time: his approach to ‚Äúfood as medicine‚Äù inspired a lot of what I built at Instacart, and his focus on finding the root causes of illness inspired a lot of my healthcare initiatives. Here we talk about my personal health journey, the launch of ChatGPT Health and how OpenAI is approaching healthcare, and what I‚Äôm building to cure chronic illnesses at ChronicleBio. Thanks Mark for the great convo!
